In case of PFC WD we run an arbitrary .lua plugin on Counters DB to check if storm condition is met. According to design, it is going to receive notification from .lua script indicating that queue state changed.
It would be better to have oids in serializable format in order for watchdog to just deserialize them without modification.

Fixed review remarks from #223. 
The description of PR is added below. 

The changes have a following goals:
- Add and update queue's counters for each port to Counter DB
- Read and store the SAI oids for ports and queues once on init instead of polling the SAI each time when counters are updating
Updated the implementation to use Flex counter for review. Under manual testing.

conflict?

if we let syncd to collect counter and then run the storm detection and then generate the notification, we do not really need to put the data into redis db, and use lua script to analyze the data. 

the reason we have orchagent and syncd is to split the functionality, making syncd to only do simple jobs and most of bussiness logic in orchagent.

In the original design, the syncd is only pulling the counters and orchagent is handle all to detection logic. I think it should be still kept in this way.

after syncd pull the counters every 100ms, it should call the lua script (the lua script should be installed into db by swss process, not the syncd process). the lua script itself can generate notification to swss to handle, not via sai notification. Here the only thing syncd needs to do is to pull the counters and then call the lua script. 

This will be easier for us the change the pfc storm detection algorithm if there is bug. In that case, we can remove the lua script (syncd will stop calling lua script since it does not exist), and install a new lua script. The orchagent needs to be restart, but not the syncd.

What is purpose of this change? there is already saidump tool which dumps redis database to file

To @kcudnik 
The purpose of this change is to dump the real SAI state including SDK log. 
The "saidump" tool dumps only the sairedis database - not a SAI layer and it could be different. 
It is new feature introduced for dumping the SAI and SDK log and add them to sysdump.
This could be done easier if you would use connect to existign sai with INIT == false, similar like saidiscovery tool

@kcudnik i think we still need this to return true but add 0 as a valid VLAN ID internally.

@stcheng I can add VLAN 0 to VLANs list internally as it is done for default VLAN. But this will affect other components (port and router interface assume that VLAN 0 is invalid value). @lguohan @kcudnik are you agree with suggestion to add VLAN 0 internally? It would nice to have a possibility to specify a range of allowed values for attributes but it seems that this is not supported.

this zeros out the last 6 bits of mac, but the problem is that we may have two mlnx switches to be neighbor and their mgmt mac differnece is with the last 6 bits of the mac.  Then, the will have the same mac.

All our switches do have 128 MAC addresses reserved per switch.
It means that MAC from this interval might be used:

                XX:XX:XX:XX:XX:80 - XX:XX:XX:XX:XX:FF (last 7 bits)

What I do is write “zero” into the last 6 bits. So I leave 1 bit to make unique MAC address for each device.

Please keep loglevel functionality since its SWSS_LOG_ and its different from SAI API log levels
SAI LOG levels should be next to that

@kcudnik 
SAI loglevels are a subset of what SWSS supports
https://github.com/Azure/sonic-sairedis/pull/151/files#diff-91b3e380b7f6f4a0a048ca8296a12e0dR1605
So you can set any SAI loglevel using SWSS
SWSS log levels are defined here https://github.com/Azure/sonic-swss-common/blob/master/common/logger.h#L21 and even if they match sai log levels this is coincidenc rather than by design
Changed logic so that syncd handles SAI loglevels explicitly without mapping from swss
